LEFT.haxe_doc: * Generic value for "left" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

RIGHT.haxe_doc: * Generic value for "right" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

UP.haxe_doc: * Generic value for "up" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

DOWN.haxe_doc: * Generic value for "down" Used by facing, allowCollisions, and touching.

NONE.haxe_doc: * Special-case const meaning no collisions, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

CEILING.haxe_doc: * Special-case const meaning up, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

FLOOR.haxe_doc: * Special-case const meaning down, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

WALL.haxe_doc: * Special-case const meaning only the left and right sides, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

ANY.haxe_doc: * Special-case const meaning any direction, used mainly by allowCollisions and touching.

OVERLAP_BIAS.haxe_doc:
* The number of pixels the overlap can have before it won't count.
* Default value is 4, should be enough for normal games 16x16 or so
* for bigger game you may need to increase this to avoid entering on the map.
* (Used in separateX() and separateY()).

PREVENT_OVERLAP.haxe_doc:
* If we want to prevent overlapping of colliding objects.
* This is useful to prevent that one objects move inside another a few pixels.

PATH_FORWARD.haxe_doc: * Path behavior controls: move from the start of the path to the end then stop.

PATH_BACKWARD.haxe_doc: * Path behavior controls: move from the end of the path to the start then stop.

PATH_LOOP_FORWARD.haxe_doc: * Path behavior controls: move from the start of the path to the end then directly back to the start, and start over.

PATH_LOOP_BACKWARD.haxe_doc: * Path behavior controls: move from the end of the path to the start then directly back to the end, and start over.

PATH_YOYO.haxe_doc: * Path behavior controls: move from the start of the path to the end then turn around and go back to the start, over and over.

PATH_HORIZONTAL_ONLY.haxe_doc: * Path behavior controls: ignores any vertical component to the path data, only follows side to side.

PATH_VERTICAL_ONLY.haxe_doc: * Path behavior controls: ignores any horizontal component to the path data, only follows up and down.

_pZero.haxe_doc: * Should always represent (0,0) - useful for different things, for avoiding unnecessary new calls.

x.haxe_doc: * X position of the upper left corner of this object in world space.

y.haxe_doc: * Y position of the upper left corner of this object in world space.

immovable.haxe_doc: * Whether an object will move/alter position after a collision.

immovableX.haxe_doc: * Whether an object will move/alter position after a collision in the X.

immovableY.haxe_doc: * Whether an object will move/alter position after a collision in the Y axis.

velocity.haxe_doc: * The basic speed of this object.

mass.haxe_doc: * The virtual mass of the object. Default value is 1. * Currently only used with elasticity during collision resolution. * Change at your own risk; effects seem crazy unpredictable so far!

elasticity.haxe_doc: * The bounciness of this object. Only affects collisions. Default value is 0, or "not bouncy at all."

acceleration.haxe_doc: * How fast the speed of this object is changing. * Useful for smooth movement and gravity.

drag.haxe_doc: * This isn't drag exactly, more like deceleration that is only applied * when acceleration is not affecting the sprite.

maxVelocity.haxe_doc: * If you are using acceleration, you can use maxVelocity with it * to cap the speed automatically (very useful!).

angle.haxe_doc: * Set the angle of a sprite to rotate it. * WARNING: rotating sprites decreases rendering * performance for this sprite by a factor of 10x!

angularVelocity.haxe_doc: * This is how fast you want this sprite to spin.

angularAcceleration.haxe_doc: * How fast the spin speed should change.

maxAngular.haxe_doc: * Use in conjunction with angularAcceleration for fluid spin speed control.

scrollFactor.haxe_doc: * A point that can store numbers from 0 to 1 (for X and Y independently) * that governs how much this object is affected by the camera subsystem. * 0 means it never moves, like a HUD element or far background graphic. * 1 means it scrolls along a the same speed as the foreground layer. * scrollFactor is initialized as (1,1) by default.

_flicker.haxe_doc: * Internal helper used for retro-style flickering.

_flickerTimer.haxe_doc: * Internal helper used for retro-style flickering.

health.haxe_doc: * Handy for storing health percentage or armor points or whatever.

_point.haxe_doc: * This is just a pre-allocated x-y point container to be used however you like

_rect.haxe_doc: * This is just a pre-allocated rectangle container to be used however you like

moves.haxe_doc: * Set this to false if you want to skip the automatic motion/movement stuff (see updateMotion()). * SpiObject and SpiSprite default to true. * SpiText, SpiTileblock and SpiTilemap default to false.

touching.haxe_doc: * Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating surface contacts. * Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here, or use touching(), justStartedTouching(), etc. * You can even use them broadly as boolean values if you're feeling saucy!

wasTouching.haxe_doc: * Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating surface contacts from the previous game loop step. * Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here, or use touching(), justStartedTouching(), etc. * You can even use them broadly as boolean values if you're feeling saucy!

allowCollisions.haxe_doc: * Bit field of flags (use with UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT, etc) indicating collision directions. * Use bitwise operators to check the values stored here. * Useful for things like one-way platforms (e.g. allowCollisions = UP;) * The accessor "solid" just flips this variable between NONE and ANY.

last.haxe_doc: * Important variable for collision processing. * By default this value is set automatically during preUpdate().

path.haxe_doc: * A reference to a path object. Null by default, assigned by followPath().

pathSpeed.haxe_doc: * The speed at which the object is moving on the path. * When an object completes a non-looping path circuit, * the pathSpeed will be zeroed out, but the path reference * will NOT be nulled out. So pathSpeed is a good way * to check if this object is currently following a path or not.

pathAngle.haxe_doc: * The angle in degrees between this object and the next node, where 0 is directly upward, and 90 is to the right.

_pathNodeIndex.haxe_doc: * Internal helper, tracks which node of the path this object is moving toward.

_pathMode.haxe_doc: * Internal tracker for path behavior flags (like looping, horizontal only, etc).

_pathInc.haxe_doc: * Internal helper for node navigation, specifically yo-yo and backwards movement.

_pathRotate.haxe_doc: * Internal flag for whether the object's angle should be adjusted to the path angle during path follow behavior.

_lastTouching.haxe_doc:
* The information about the last collision.
* You can use it on the postCollision method.

class.haxe_doc:
* This is the base class for most of the display objects
* (SpiSprite, SpiText, etc).
* It includes some basic attributes about game objects,
* including retro-style flickering, basic state information,
* sizes, scrolling, and basic physics and motion.
*
* v1.0 Initial version * * @version 1.0 - 17/07/2013 * @author ratalaika / ratalaikaGames * @author Ka Wing Chin * @author Thomas Weston

roundDecimal.haxe_doc: * Round to the closes number with the number of decimals given. E.g round(2.954165, 2) == 2.95 * * @param num The number to round. * @param dec The number of decimals wanted. * @return The rounded value of that number.

bound.haxe_doc: * Bound a number by a minimum and maximum. Ensures that this number is * no smaller than the minimum, and no larger than the maximum. * Leaving a bound null means that side is unbounded. * * @param Value Any number. * @param Min Any number. * @param Max Any number. * @return The bounded value of the number.

pointInCoordinates.haxe_doc: * Returns true if the given x/y coordinate is within the given rectangular block * * @param pointX The X value to test * @param pointY The Y value to test * @param rectX The X value of the region to test within * @param rectY The Y value of the region to test within * @param rectWidth The width of the region to test within * @param rectHeight The height of the region to test within * * @return true if pointX/pointY is within the region, otherwise false

pointInSpiRect.haxe_doc: * Returns true if the given x/y coordinate is within the given rectangular block * * @param pointX The X value to test * @param pointY The Y value to test * @param rect The SpiRect to test within * @return true if pointX/pointY is within the SpiRect, otherwise false

wrapValue.haxe_doc:
* Adds value to amount and ensures that the result always stays between 0 and max, by wrapping the value around. *

Values must be positive integers, and are passed through Math.abs

* * @param value The value to add the amount to * @param amount The amount to add to the value * @param max The maximum the value is allowed to be * @return The wrapped value

vectorLength.haxe_doc: * Finds the length of the given vector * * @param dx * @param dy * * @return

getDistance.haxe_doc: * Calculate the distance between two points. * * @param Point1 A SpiPoint object referring to the first location. * @param Point2 A SpiPoint object referring to the second location. * @return The distance between the two points as a floating point Number object.

class.haxe_doc: * Adds a set of fast Math functions and extends a few commonly used ones. * * v1.1 Updated some references and commented * v1.0 Initial version * * @version 1.1 - 27/02/2013 * @author ratalaika / ratalaikaGames * @author Richard Davey / Photon Storm

x.haxe_doc: * The X coordinate of the point.

y.haxe_doc: * The Y coordinate of the point.

getLeft.haxe_doc: * The X coordinate of the left side of the rectangle. Read-only.

getRight.haxe_doc: * The X coordinate of the right side of the rectangle. Read-only.

getTop.haxe_doc: * The Y coordinate of the top of the rectangle. Read-only.

getBottom.haxe_doc: * The Y coordinate of the bottom of the rectangle. Read-only.

make.haxe_doc: * Instantiate a new rectangle. * * @param X The X-coordinate of the point in space. * @param Y The Y-coordinate of the point in space. * @param Width Desired width of the rectangle. * @param Height Desired height of the rectangle. * * @return A reference to itself.

copyFrom.haxe_doc: * Helper function, just copies the values from the specified rectangle. * * @param Rect Any SpiRect. * * @return A reference to itself.

copyTo.haxe_doc: * Helper function, just copies the values from this rectangle to the specified rectangle. * * @param Point Any SpiRect. * * @return A reference to the altered rectangle parameter.

copyFromFlash.haxe_doc: * Helper function, just copies the values from the specified libgdx rectangle. * * @param FlashRect Any Rectangle. * * @return A reference to itself.

copyToFlash.haxe_doc: * Helper function, just copies the values from this rectangle to the specified libgdx rectangle. * * @param Point Any Rectangle. * * @return A reference to the altered rectangle parameter.

overlaps.haxe_doc: * Checks to see if some SpiRect object overlaps this SpiRect object. * * @param Rect The rectangle being tested. * * @return Whether or not the two rectangles overlap.

contains.haxe_doc: * Check if the given coordinates are contained in the rectangle. * * @param x The X coordinate. * @param y The Y coordinate.

containsPoint.haxe_doc: * Check if the given coordinates are contained in the rectangle. * * @param point The point with the coordinates.

containsRect.haxe_doc: * Check if the given rectangle is contained in the rectangle. * * @param rect The rectangle.

intersection.haxe_doc: * Returns the intersection of two rectangles. * * @param toIntersect * @return

intersects.haxe_doc: * Check if two rectangles intersect. * * @param toIntersect * @return

isEmpty.haxe_doc: * Check if the rectangle is empty. * @return

print.haxe_doc: * Returns the values in a printable format. * @return

offset.haxe_doc: * Adjusts the location of the rectangle object. * * @param dx * @param dy

new.haxe_doc: * Instantiate a new rectangle. * * @param X The X-coordinate of the point in space. * @param Y The Y-coordinate of the point in space. * @param Width Desired width of the rectangle. * @param Height Desired height of the rectangle.

class.haxe_doc:
* Stores a rectangle.
*
* v1.0 Initial version * * @version 1.0 - 17/07/2013 * @author ratalaika / ratalaikaGames * @author Ka Wing Chin

PERSIST.haxe_doc: * Persistent Tween type, will stop when it finishes.

LOOPING.haxe_doc: * Looping Tween type, will restart immediately when it finishes.

PINGPONG.haxe_doc: * "To and from" Tween type, will play tween hither and thither

ONESHOT.haxe_doc: * Oneshot Tween type, will stop and remove itself from its core container when it finishes.

BACKWARD.haxe_doc: * Backward Tween type, will play tween in reverse direction

active.haxe_doc: * True if the tweening is active.

complete.haxe_doc: * This method will be called when the tween complete.

percent.haxe_doc: * The period of time that tween has completed.

_ease.haxe_doc: * The easer method to apply to the Tweened value.

_time.haxe_doc: * The time that has passed since the tween started.

_target.haxe_doc: * Duration of the tween (in seconds or frames).

isFinished.haxe_doc: * True if the tweening has finished.

_backward.haxe_doc: * If the tween has to be played in a reverse direction.

update.haxe_doc: * Updates the Tween, called by World.

start.haxe_doc: * Starts the Tween, or restarts it if it's currently running.

cancel.haxe_doc: * Immediately stops the Tween and removes it from its Tweener without calling the complete callback.

getPercent.haxe_doc: * Get the percent of completed tween. * * @return

setPercent.haxe_doc: * Set the percent. * * @param value The percent value. * @return

new.haxe_doc: * Constructor. Specify basic information about the Tween. * @param duration Duration of the tween (in seconds or frames). * @param type Tween type, one of Tween.PERSIST (default), Tween.LOOPING, or Tween.ONESHOT. * @param complete Optional callback for when the Tween completes. * @param ease Optional easer method to apply to the Tweened value.

class.haxe_doc: * The global tween class. * * v1.1 Ported to Java * v1.0 Initial version (?) * * @version 1.1 - January 24th 2013 * @author ratalaika / ratalaikaGames

abstract.haxe_doc: * Class representing a color, based on Int. Provides a variety of methods for creating and converting colors. * * SpiColor's can be written as Ints. This means you can pass a hex value such as * 0xff123456 to a function expecting a SpiColor, and it will automatically become a SpiColor object. * Similarly, SpiColors may be treated as Ints. * * Note that when using properties of a SpiColor other than ARGB, the values are ultimately stored as * ARGB values, so repeatedly manipulating HSB/HSL/CMYK values may result in a gradual loss of precision. * * @author Joe Williamson (JoeCreates)

colorLookup.haxe_doc: * A Map<String, Int> which values are the static colors of SpiColor. * You can add more colors for SpiColor.fromString(String) if you need.

hue.haxe_doc: * The hue of the color in degrees (from 0 to 359)

saturation.haxe_doc: * The saturation of the color (from 0 to 1)

brightness.haxe_doc: * The brightness (aka value) of the color (from 0 to 1)

lightness.haxe_doc: * The lightness of the color (from 0 to 1)

fromInt.haxe_doc: * Create a color from the lest significant four bytes of an Int * * @param Value And Int with bytes in the format 0xAARRGGBB * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromRGB.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from integer RGB values (0 to 255) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 255 * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromRGBFloat.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from float RGB values (0 to 1) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromCMYK.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from CMYK values (0 to 1) * * @param Cyan The cyan value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Magenta The magenta value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Yellow The yellow value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Black The black value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromHSB.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from HSB (aka HSV) components. * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Brightness (aka Value) A number between 0 and 1, indicating how bright the color should be. 0 is black, 1 is full bright. * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255. * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromHSL.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from HSL components. * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Lightness A number between 0 and 1, indicating the lightness of the color * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255. * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromString.haxe_doc: * Parses a String and returns a SpiColor or null if the String couldn't be parsed. * Examples (input -> output in hex): * 0x00FF00 -> 0xFF00FF00 * 0xAA4578C2 -> 0xAA4578C2 * #0000FF -> 0xFF0000FF * #3F000011 -> 0x3F000011 * GRAY -> 0xFF808080 * blue -> 0xFF0000FF * @param str The string to be parsed * @return A SpiColor or null if the String couldn't be parsed

getHSBColorWheel.haxe_doc: * Get HSB color wheel values in an array which will be 360 elements in size * * @param Alpha Alpha value for each color of the color wheel, between 0 (transparent) and 255 (opaque) * @return HSB color wheel as Array of SpiColors

interpolate.haxe_doc: * Get an interpolated color based on two different colors. * * @param Color1 The first color * @param Color2 The second color * @param Factor Value from 0 to 1 representing how much to shift Color1 toward Color2 * @return The interpolated color

gradient.haxe_doc: * Create a gradient from one color to another * * @param Color1 The color to shift from * @param Color2 The color to shift to * @param Steps How many colors the gradient should have * @param Ease An optional easing function, such as those provided in SpiEase * @return An array of colors of length Steps, shifting from Color1 to Color2

multiply.haxe_doc: * Multiply the RGB channels of two SpiColors

add.haxe_doc: * Add the RGB channels of two SpiColors

subtract.haxe_doc: * Subtract the RGB channels of one SpiColor from another

getComplementHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns a Complementary Color Harmony of this color. * A complementary hue is one directly opposite the color given on the color wheel * * @return The complimentary color

getAnalogousHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns an Analogous Color Harmony for the given color. * An Analogous harmony are hues adjacent to each other on the color wheel * * @param Threshold Control how adjacent the colors will be (default +- 30 degrees) * @return Object containing 3 properties: original (the original color), warmer (the warmer analogous color) and colder (the colder analogous color)

getSplitComplementHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns an Split Complement Color Harmony for this color. * A Split Complement harmony are the two hues on either side of the color's Complement * * @param Threshold Control how adjacent the colors will be to the Complement (default +- 30 degrees) * @return Object containing 3 properties: original (the original color), warmer (the warmer analogous color) and colder (the colder analogous color)

getTriadicHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns a Triadic Color Harmony for this color. A Triadic harmony are 3 hues equidistant * from each other on the color wheel. * * @return Object containing 3 properties: color1 (the original color), color2 and color3 (the equidistant colors)

to24Bit.haxe_doc: * Return a 24 bit version of this color (i.e. without an alpha value) * * @return A 24 bit version of this color

toHexString.haxe_doc: * Return a String representation of the color in the format * * @param Alpha Whether to include the alpha value in the hes string * @param Prefix Whether to include "0x" prefix at start of string * @return A string of length 10 in the format 0xAARRGGBB

toWebString.haxe_doc: * Return a String representation of the color in the format #RRGGBB * * @return A string of length 7 in the format #RRGGBB

getColorInfo.haxe_doc: * Get a string of color information about this color * * @return A string containing information about this color

getDarkened.haxe_doc: * Get a darkened version of this color * * @param Factor Value from 0 to 1 of how much to progress toward black. * @return A darkened version of this color

getLightened.haxe_doc: * Get a lightened version of this color * * @param Factor Value from 0 to 1 of how much to progress toward white. * @return A lightened version of this color

getInverted.haxe_doc: * Get the inversion of this color * * @return The inversion of this color

setRGB.haxe_doc: * Set RGB values as integers (0 to 255) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 255 * @return This color

setRGBFloat.haxe_doc: * Set RGB values as floats (0 to 1) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return This color

setCMYK.haxe_doc: * Set CMYK values as floats (0 to 1) * * @param Cyan The cyan value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Magenta The magenta value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Yellow The yellow value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Black The black value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return This color

setHSB.haxe_doc: * Set HSB (aka HSV) components * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Brightness (aka Value) A number between 0 and 1, indicating how bright the color should be. 0 is black, 1 is full bright. * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255. * @return This color

setHSL.haxe_doc: * Set HSL components. * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Lightness A number between 0 and 1, indicating the lightness of the color * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255 * @return This color

setHSChromaMatch.haxe_doc: * Private utility function to perform common operations between setHSB and setHSL

colorLookup.haxe_doc: * A Map<String, Int> which values are the static colors of SpiColor. * You can add more colors for SpiColor.fromString(String) if you need.

hue.haxe_doc: * The hue of the color in degrees (from 0 to 359)

saturation.haxe_doc: * The saturation of the color (from 0 to 1)

brightness.haxe_doc: * The brightness (aka value) of the color (from 0 to 1)

lightness.haxe_doc: * The lightness of the color (from 0 to 1)

fromInt.haxe_doc: * Create a color from the lest significant four bytes of an Int * * @param Value And Int with bytes in the format 0xAARRGGBB * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromRGB.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from integer RGB values (0 to 255) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 255 * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromRGBFloat.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from float RGB values (0 to 1) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromCMYK.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from CMYK values (0 to 1) * * @param Cyan The cyan value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Magenta The magenta value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Yellow The yellow value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Black The black value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromHSB.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from HSB (aka HSV) components. * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Brightness (aka Value) A number between 0 and 1, indicating how bright the color should be. 0 is black, 1 is full bright. * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255. * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromHSL.haxe_doc: * Generate a color from HSL components. * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Lightness A number between 0 and 1, indicating the lightness of the color * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255. * @return The color as a SpiColor

fromString.haxe_doc: * Parses a String and returns a SpiColor or null if the String couldn't be parsed. * Examples (input -> output in hex): * 0x00FF00 -> 0xFF00FF00 * 0xAA4578C2 -> 0xAA4578C2 * #0000FF -> 0xFF0000FF * #3F000011 -> 0x3F000011 * GRAY -> 0xFF808080 * blue -> 0xFF0000FF * @param str The string to be parsed * @return A SpiColor or null if the String couldn't be parsed

getHSBColorWheel.haxe_doc: * Get HSB color wheel values in an array which will be 360 elements in size * * @param Alpha Alpha value for each color of the color wheel, between 0 (transparent) and 255 (opaque) * @return HSB color wheel as Array of SpiColors

interpolate.haxe_doc: * Get an interpolated color based on two different colors. * * @param Color1 The first color * @param Color2 The second color * @param Factor Value from 0 to 1 representing how much to shift Color1 toward Color2 * @return The interpolated color

gradient.haxe_doc: * Create a gradient from one color to another * * @param Color1 The color to shift from * @param Color2 The color to shift to * @param Steps How many colors the gradient should have * @param Ease An optional easing function, such as those provided in SpiEase * @return An array of colors of length Steps, shifting from Color1 to Color2

multiply.haxe_doc: * Multiply the RGB channels of two SpiColors

add.haxe_doc: * Add the RGB channels of two SpiColors

subtract.haxe_doc: * Subtract the RGB channels of one SpiColor from another

getComplementHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns a Complementary Color Harmony of this color. * A complementary hue is one directly opposite the color given on the color wheel * * @return The complimentary color

getAnalogousHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns an Analogous Color Harmony for the given color. * An Analogous harmony are hues adjacent to each other on the color wheel * * @param Threshold Control how adjacent the colors will be (default +- 30 degrees) * @return Object containing 3 properties: original (the original color), warmer (the warmer analogous color) and colder (the colder analogous color)

getSplitComplementHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns an Split Complement Color Harmony for this color. * A Split Complement harmony are the two hues on either side of the color's Complement * * @param Threshold Control how adjacent the colors will be to the Complement (default +- 30 degrees) * @return Object containing 3 properties: original (the original color), warmer (the warmer analogous color) and colder (the colder analogous color)

getTriadicHarmony.haxe_doc: * Returns a Triadic Color Harmony for this color. A Triadic harmony are 3 hues equidistant * from each other on the color wheel. * * @return Object containing 3 properties: color1 (the original color), color2 and color3 (the equidistant colors)

to24Bit.haxe_doc: * Return a 24 bit version of this color (i.e. without an alpha value) * * @return A 24 bit version of this color

toHexString.haxe_doc: * Return a String representation of the color in the format * * @param Alpha Whether to include the alpha value in the hes string * @param Prefix Whether to include "0x" prefix at start of string * @return A string of length 10 in the format 0xAARRGGBB

toWebString.haxe_doc: * Return a String representation of the color in the format #RRGGBB * * @return A string of length 7 in the format #RRGGBB

getColorInfo.haxe_doc: * Get a string of color information about this color * * @return A string containing information about this color

getDarkened.haxe_doc: * Get a darkened version of this color * * @param Factor Value from 0 to 1 of how much to progress toward black. * @return A darkened version of this color

getLightened.haxe_doc: * Get a lightened version of this color * * @param Factor Value from 0 to 1 of how much to progress toward white. * @return A lightened version of this color

getInverted.haxe_doc: * Get the inversion of this color * * @return The inversion of this color

setRGB.haxe_doc: * Set RGB values as integers (0 to 255) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 255 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 255 * @return This color

setRGBFloat.haxe_doc: * Set RGB values as floats (0 to 1) * * @param Red The red value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Green The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Blue The green value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return This color

setCMYK.haxe_doc: * Set CMYK values as floats (0 to 1) * * @param Cyan The cyan value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Magenta The magenta value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Yellow The yellow value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Black The black value of the color from 0 to 1 * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, from 0 to 1 * @return This color

setHSB.haxe_doc: * Set HSB (aka HSV) components * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Brightness (aka Value) A number between 0 and 1, indicating how bright the color should be. 0 is black, 1 is full bright. * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255. * @return This color

setHSL.haxe_doc: * Set HSL components. * * @param Hue A number between 0 and 360, indicating position on a color strip or wheel. * @param Saturation A number between 0 and 1, indicating how colorful or gray the color should be. 0 is gray, 1 is vibrant. * @param Lightness A number between 0 and 1, indicating the lightness of the color * @param Alpha How opaque the color should be, either between 0 and 1 or 0 and 255 * @return This color

setHSChromaMatch.haxe_doc: * Private utility function to perform common operations between setHSB and setHSL

destroy.haxe_doc: * Checks if an object is not null before calling destroy(), always returns null. * * @param object An ISpiDestroyable object that will be destroyed if it's not null.

destroyArray.haxe_doc: * Destroy every element of an array of ISpiDestroyables * * @param array An Array of ISpiDestroyable objects

put.haxe_doc: * Checks if an object is not null before putting it back into the pool, always returns null. * * @param object An ISpiPoolable object that will be put back into the pool if it's not null

putArray.haxe_doc: * Puts all objects in an Array of ISpiPoolable objects back into * the pool by calling SpiDestroyUtil.put() on them * * @param array An Array of ISpiPoolable objects * @return null

class.haxe_doc:
* Handy manager for pooling and destroying objects. * * v1.0 Initial version
*
* @version 1.0 - 18/04/2015 * @author ratalaika / ratalaikaGames

nodes.haxe_doc: * The list of SpiPoints that make up the path data.

debugColor.haxe_doc: * Specify a debug display color for the path. Default is white.

debugScrollFactor.haxe_doc: * Specify a debug display scroll factor for the path. Default is (1,1). * NOTE: does not affect world movement! Object scroll factors take care of that.

ignoreDrawDebug.haxe_doc: * Setting this to true will prevent the object from appearing * when the visual debug mode in the debugger overlay is toggled on. * @default false

_point.haxe_doc: * Internal helper for keeping new variable instantiations under control.

add.haxe_doc: * Add a new node to the end of the path at the specified location. * * @param X X position of the new path point in world coordinates. * @param Y Y position of the new path point in world coordinates.

addAt.haxe_doc: * Add a new node to the path at the specified location and index within the path. * * @param X X position of the new path point in world coordinates. * @param Y Y position of the new path point in world coordinates. * @param Index Where within the list of path nodes to insert this new point.

addPoint.haxe_doc: * Sometimes its easier or faster to just pass a point object instead of separate X and Y coordinates. * This also gives you the option of not creating a new node but actually adding that specific * SpiPoint object to the path. This allows you to do neat things, like dynamic paths. * * @param Node The point in world coordinates you want to add to the path. * @param AsReference Whether to add the point as a reference, or to create a new point with the specified values.

addPointAt.haxe_doc: * Sometimes its easier or faster to just pass a point object instead of separate X and Y coordinates. * This also gives you the option of not creating a new node but actually adding that specific * SpiPoint object to the path. This allows you to do neat things, like dynamic paths. * * @param Node The point in world coordinates you want to add to the path. * @param Index Where within the list of path nodes to insert this new point. * @param AsReference Whether to add the point as a reference, or to create a new point with the specified values.

remove.haxe_doc: * Remove a node from the path. * NOTE: only works with points added by reference or with references from nodes itself! * * @param Node The point object you want to remove from the path. * * @return The node that was excised. Returns null if the node was not found.

removeAt.haxe_doc: * Remove a node from the path using the specified position in the list of path nodes. * * @param Index Where within the list of path nodes you want to remove a node. * * @return The node that was excised. Returns null if there were no nodes in the path.

head.haxe_doc: * Get the first node in the list. * * @return The first node in the path.

tail.haxe_doc: * Get the last node in the list. * * @return The last node in the path.

drawDebug.haxe_doc: * While this doesn't override SpiBasic.drawDebug(), the behavior is very similar. * Based on this path data, it draws a simple lines-and-boxes representation of the path * if the visual debug mode was toggled in the debugger overlay. You can use debugColor * and debugScrollFactor to control the path's appearance. * * @param Camera The camera object the path will draw to.

new.haxe_doc: * Instantiate a new path object. * * @param Nodes Optional, can specify all the points for the path up front if you want.

class.haxe_doc:
* This is a simple path data container. Basically a list of points that
* a SpiObject can follow. Also has code for drawing debug visuals.
* SpiTilemap.findPath() returns a path object, but you can
* also just make your own, using the add() functions below
* or by creating your own array of points.
*
* v1.0 Initial version * * @version 1.0 - 17/07/2013 * @author ratalaika / ratalaikaGames * @author Thomas Weston * @author Ka Wing Chin

formatTicks.haxe_doc: * Takes two "ticks" timestamps and formats them into the number of seconds that passed as a String. * Useful for logging, debugging, the watch window, or whatever else. * * @param StartTicks The first timestamp from the system. * @param EndTicks The second timestamp from the system. * @return A String containing the formatted time elapsed information.

formatTime.haxe_doc: * Format seconds as minutes with a colon, an optionally with milliseconds too. * * @param Seconds The number of seconds (for example, time remaining, time spent, etc). * @param ShowMS Whether to show milliseconds after a "." as well. Default value is false. * @return A nicely formatted String, like "1:03".

formatArray.haxe_doc: * Generate a comma-separated string from an array. * Especially useful for tracing or other debug output. * * @param AnyArray Any Array object. * @return A comma-separated String containing the .toString() output of each element in the array.

formatStringMap.haxe_doc: * Generate a comma-seperated string representation of the keys of a StringMap. * * @param AnyMap A StringMap object. * @return A String formatted like this: key1, key2, ..., keyX

formatMoney.haxe_doc: * Automatically commas and decimals in the right places for displaying money amounts. * Does not include a dollar sign or anything, so doesn't really do much * if you call say var results:String = SpiString.formatMoney(10,false); * However, very handy for displaying large sums or decimal money values. * * @param Amount How much moneys (in dollars, or the equivalent "main" currency - i.e. not cents). * @param ShowDecimal Whether to show the decimals/cents component. Default value is true. * @param EnglishStyle Major quantities (thousands, millions, etc) separated by commas, and decimal by a period. Default value is true. * @return A nicely formatted String. Does not include a dollar sign or anything!

formatBytes.haxe_doc: * Takes an amount of bytes and finds the fitting unit. Makes sure that the * value is below 1024. Example: formatBytes(123456789); -> 117.74MB

filterDigits.haxe_doc: * Takes a string and filters out everything but the digits. * * @param Input The input string * @return The output string, digits-only

htmlFormat.haxe_doc: * Format a text with html tags - useful for TextField.htmlText. * Used by the log window of the debugger. * * @param Text The text to format * @param Size The text size, using the font-size-tag * @param Color The text color, using font-color-tag * @param Bold Whether the text should be bold (b-tag) * @param Italic Whether the text should be italic (i-tag) * @param Underlined Whether the text should be underlined (u-tag) * @return The html-formatted text.

getDomain.haxe_doc: * Returns the domain of a URL.

sameClassName.haxe_doc: * Helper function that uses getClassName to compare two objects' class names. * * @param Obj1 The first object * @param Obj2 The second object * @param Simple Only uses the class name, not the package or packages. * @return Whether they have the same class name or not

toIntArray.haxe_doc: * Split a comma-separated string into an array of ints * * @param Data String formatted like this: "1, 2, 5, -10, 120, 27" * @return An array of ints

toFloatArray.haxe_doc: * Split a comma-separated string into an array of floats * * @param Data string formatted like this: "1.0,2.1,5.6,1245587.9, -0.00354" * @return An array of floats

arrayToCSV.haxe_doc: * Converts a one-dimensional array of tile data to a comma-separated string. * * @param Data An array full of integer tile references. * @param Width The number of tiles in each row. * @param Invert Recommended only for 1-bit arrays - changes 0s to 1s and vice versa. * @return A comma-separated string containing the level data in a SpiTilemap-friendly format.

getDebugString.haxe_doc: * Helper function to create a string for toString() functions. Automatically rounds values according to SpiG.debugger.precision. * Strings are formatted in the format: (x: 50 | y: 60 | visible: false) * * @param LabelValuePairs Array with the data for the string

class.haxe_doc: * A class primarily containing functions related * to formatting different data types to strings.

uid.haxe_doc: the user id for the file

mtime.haxe_doc: the last modification time for the file

gid.haxe_doc: the user group id for the file

ctime.haxe_doc: the creation time for the file

atime.haxe_doc: the last access time for the file (when enabled by the file system)

exists.haxe_doc:
Tells if the file or directory specified by `path` exists.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

rename.haxe_doc:
Renames/moves the file or directory specified by `path` to `newPath`.
If `path` is not a valid file system entry, or if it is not accessible, or if `newPath` is not accessible, an exception is thrown.
If `path` or `newPath` are null, the result is unspecified.

stat.haxe_doc:
Returns `FileStat` information on the file or directory specified by `path`.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

fullPath.haxe_doc:
Returns the full path of the file or directory specified by `relPath`, which is relative to the current working directory. Symlinks will be followed and the path will be normalized.
If `relPath` is null, the result is unspecified.

absolutePath.haxe_doc:
Returns the full path of the file or directory specified by `relPath`, which is relative to the current working directory. The path doesn't have to exist.
If `relPath` is null, the result is unspecified.

isDirectory.haxe_doc:
Tells if the file or directory specified by `path` is a directory.
If `path` is not a valid file system entry or if its destination is no accessible, an exception is thrown.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

createDirectory.haxe_doc:
Creates a directory specified by `path`.
This method is recursive: The parent directories don't have to exist.
If the directory cannot be created, an exception is thrown.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

deleteFile.haxe_doc:
Deletes the file specified by `path`.
If `path` does not denote a valid file, or if that file cannot be deleted, an exception is thrown.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

deleteDirectory.haxe_doc:
Deletes the directory specified by `path`.
If `path` does not denote a valid directory, or if that directory cannot be deleted, an exception is thrown.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

readDirectory.haxe_doc:
Returns the names of all files and directories in the directory specified by `path`.
If `path` does not denote a valid directory, an exception is thrown.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

class.haxe_doc:
This class allows you to get information about the files and directories.
See `sys.io.File` for the complementary file API.

getContent.haxe_doc:
Retrieves the content of the file specified by `path` as a String.
If the file does not exist or can not be read, an exception is thrown.
`sys.FileSystem.exists` can be used to check for existence.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

saveContent.haxe_doc:
Stores `content` in the file specified by `path`.
If the file cannot be written to, an exception is thrown.
If `path` or `content` are null, the result is unspecified.

getBytes.haxe_doc:
Retrieves the binary content of the file specified by `path`.
If the file does not exist or can not be read, an exception is thrown.
`sys.FileSystem.exists` can be used to check for existence.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

saveBytes.haxe_doc:
Stores `bytes` in the file specified by `path` in binary mode.
If the file cannot be written to, an exception is thrown.
If `path` or `bytes` are null, the result is unspecified.

read.haxe_doc:
Returns an `FileInput` handle to the file specified by `path`.
If `binary` is true, the file is opened in binary mode. Otherwise it is opened in non-binary mode.
If the file does not exist or can not be read, an exception is thrown.
Operations on the returned `FileInput` handle read on the opened file.
File handles should be closed via `FileInput.close` once the operation is complete.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

write.haxe_doc:
Returns an `FileOutput` handle to the file specified by `path`.
If `binary` is true, the file is opened in binary mode. Otherwise it is opened in non-binary mode.
If the file cannot be written to, an exception is thrown.
Operations on the returned `FileOutput` handle write to the opened file. If the file existed, its previous content is overwritten.
File handles should be closed via `FileOutput.close` once the operation is complete.
If `path` is null, the result is unspecified.

append.haxe_doc: Similar to `sys.io.File.write`, but appends to the file if it exists instead of overwriting its contents.

copy.haxe_doc:
Copies the contents of the file specified by `srcPath` to the file specified by `dstPath`.
If the `srcPath` does not exist or cannot be read, or if the `dstPath` file cannot be written to, an exception is thrown.
If the file at `dstPath` exists, its contents are overwritten.
If `srcPath` or `dstPath` are null, the result is unspecified.

class.haxe_doc:
API for reading and writing to files.
See `sys.FileSystem` for the complementary file system API.
Use [sys.io.File.read] to create a [FileInput]
Use [sys.io.File.write] to create a [FileOutput]
